oh, sorry, it'll just check the next character with the same state

Are there general principles for how the `input` element is meant to behave in terms of user-entered values, `.value` values, and submitted values? Notably, the spec text for `email` very much goes in the direction of non-Punycode forms of the domain being an UI presentation issue only. Dates and times clearly are supposed to submit in the ISO format. Yet, `url` seems to submit what the user entered instead of submitting serialization after URL parsing.
content.formatted_body: Are there general principles for how the input element is meant to behave in terms of user-entered values, .value values, and submitted values? Notably, the spec text for email very much goes in the direction of non-Punycode forms of the domain being an UI presentation issue only. Dates and times clearly are supposed to submit in the ISO format. Yet, url seems to submit what the user entered instead of submitting serialization after URL parsing.

content.body: hsivonen: I think the more we can move towards submitting and exposing (to script) a normalized form, the better
content.formatted_body: hsivonen: I think the more we can move towards submitting and exposing (to script) a normalized form, the better

content.body: Looks like in Chrome setting email value via JS doesn't immediately normalize the value, but attempting to submit still catches a prohibited value.
When editing email manually (not via JS), if the entered value is failing constraint validation, the `.value` is unnormalized. If the value passes constraint validation, the `.value` is normalized.
content.formatted_body: When editing email manually (not via JS), if the entered value is failing constraint validation, the .value is unnormalized. If the value passes constraint validation, the .value is normalized.
